subtitle: Place your advance order now on Amazon for the very first volume of the New Thinking
Allowed Dialogue Series, Is There Life After Death?
Publication date is June 1st.
Thinking Allowed. Conversations on the leading
edge of knowledge and discovery, with psychologist
Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome. I'm Jeffrey Mishlove. Today
we are going to explore the topic of opening
to intuition. With me is Linda Tellington-Jones,
the author of The Tellington TTouch. Linda
is known throughout the world for her work with
animals and her pioneering development of the
Tellington TTouch method. She is the founder and
president of the Tellington TTouch organization.
There are now 2,500 people trained in her
methodology, working on every continent except
South Antarctica, I suppose, all over the world. Welcome, Linda.
Thank you. It is a real pleasure for me to be with you.
It is a pleasure to be with you. In our earlier
discussions, it seems as if we have been traveling
in some of the same circles for many, many years.
For all I know, we bumped into each other several
times without realizing it.
We must have crossed in the hallway.
It would seem as if we may have even shared the same room as an office at one time.
Yes, isn't that fascinating?
In San Francisco, most amazing. So you have been on quite a journey in your lifetime,
and you've been a student of various wisdom teachers and teachers of intuition for many
decades, and that's really what led you to develop your own pioneering work.
Absolutely. It was actually where my spiritual
path and my whole concept of intuition began was
1972 at Esalen Institute when Robert Monroe
from the Monroe Institute was giving a weekend
workshop, an invitational workshop for 40 people,
and Russell Tark was there actually measuring
all of us. When he looked at my results and
said to me that I had as close to a 50-50 use of
logic and intuition, left and right hemispheres,
I was totally surprised because I never thought
of myself as logical. So I thought, okay, I'm
basically a teacher, and I thought, how do we
develop this left and right hemisphere, this
intuition and logic? So into my hands somehow
came this amazing book, Drawing from the Right
Side of the Brain from Betty Edwards, a classic
book, and I started practicing for months in my
mind, drawing my name backwards, writing words
backwards with the right hand and with the left hand, doing all of these exercises.
What's really interesting, Jeffrey, is that I
didn't realize the role that Robert Monroe had
played until I actually was answering questions
for a book that just came out two days ago about
me. It's called Linda, Trust Your Intuition,
and I didn't realize until I started thinking,
okay, what started me on this spiritual path? I
didn't even really know what the Monroe Institute
did because I'd never looked at their website,
and that whole thing of intuition and all that
the amazing Monroe Institute teaches, that's
been a basis for that and for those words from
Russell Tark all these years. Well, of course,
Robert Monroe is famous for his out-of-body
experiences, journeys out of the body, far
journeys. Way up there. Yeah, and so I'm assuming
that's what this Esalen workshop was about.
That's what it was, and we did this HemiThink,
and as it happened, as we were sharing after Among
the 40 People, Joan Halifax and I had the same
vision. We connected to the same cry of an
eagle, and so we started talking about it after,
and she asked me if I would go and help Christine
Groff because her cat was having kittens and the
cat was going crazy, and she'd never seen this
before. Would I come and help? And that's how
I met Joan, and I've had many, many years of contact with her since. So this is 1972,
and you were already at this point well known
for your work with animals, I must assume.
72. Well, no, at that point, I mean, I'd had
a school for, I was known in the horse world,
and I had a school for, a residential school for
riding instructors and trainers at the Pacific
Coast Equestrian Research Farm and School of
Horsemanship, and people came to us from nine
countries and 36 states and spent these nine
months with us, but I was, I never had the time
to be on a spiritual path at that point. I mean,
for me, I had gone to church, I was raised by
parents who only knew and recognized a loving God,
and they actually, they really lived the golden
rule. They were role models for me, for prejudice was never allowed in our home,
and I was born in Edmonton, Alberta, and at that
time there was a lot of prejudice against the
people who were immigrating from Russia and, of
course, you know, Indians, but not in our home.
I see. Well, that's wonderful, and also I gather
about your childhood that you and all of your
siblings were into horses. Well, yes. In fact,
competed. Well, yes, and the thing is that I had
to ride to school for the first six years of my
life in rural Alberta. Poor kid, right? And our
horses stayed in a stable. My horse stayed in a
stable. There were only maybe five or six of us
rode. All the rest of the kids had to ride. I mean,
to walk to school, to walk to school. You got to
ride a horse to school. That's right. My gosh. So,
for you, being around animals was something that
was part of your life from virtually the beginning.
It was, and my grandmother, for instance,
would say, don't ever kill a spider. What about
its family? And I remember my father's mother,
because at one point we lived on the farm with
him when my father was helping my grandfather
during the war on a pig and wheat farm. And
I remember my grandmother bringing like runs
into the kitchen and instead of just letting them
die, warming them up, keeping them warm until they
were strong enough to go back. And I remember my
grandfather found a nest of rabbits and he brought
a little bunny and then that rabbit would go up
the stairs and rustle around in his beard and wake
up in the morning. And I think the most unusual
was my dad who had disturbed a nest of duck eggs
when he was cutting hay. And he brought the eggs
home and we had a cat who had kittens in the
kitchen at that point. Her kittens were in a basket,
I remember, in our kitchen. And he put the eggs
with this mother cat and the kittens and several
of those chicks, or actually ducks, little ducks,
actually hatched and grew up. Were raised by the
cat? By the cat. How amazing. So you were exposed
to interspecies communication. From the very
beginning. Uh-huh. Yeah, yes. Well, that's an
unusual childhood, certainly compared to mine.
Yeah, it is. And it's also unusual that my
my parents really honored animals. Wasn't just
something, you know, that we used. It was a great
honoring. A real blessing for me. Now you mentioned
Russell Targ. I did. Who pointed out to you that
your left brain and your right brain functions
were balanced. Which is, I think most people in
psychology would say, that is a good strong sign
of a highly intuitive person. Oh, interesting. I
would think so because it means the two hemispheres
of your brain can communicate with each other.
Exactly. And that's what Tellington Tee Touch
is all about, actually. Explain that. Well,
actually, I would really love to tell you how I
first became interested in the word intuition.
Okay. Because it is as much a part of my
journey as that one meeting with Russell Targ
and Robert Monroe. But for my 30th birthday, I saw
an ad in the San Francisco Chronicle that said for
five dollars you can get an astrological chart
that is produced by the first computer. Oh, yes.
And it was in Stanford basement. Stanford University basement. I recall you wrote to
me about this and the reading you got is just
uncanny. Well, what it said, and I still have
this little booklet. It's tied with a ribbon,
actually, as it came. It said that in my lifetime,
I would develop a form of communication that would
spread around the world. And in order to do so,
I had to learn to trust my intuition. And I,
okay, I went to our library in the living room,
and my husband was 20 years older than I. I wouldn't be here if I hadn't had that
amazing experience with Wentworth Tellington. And
he had a big library and he was at that time a
study, a follower of Rosicrucian studies. And
I pulled down one of the Rosicrucian books and
opened it to intuition, and it described intuition
as unlearned knowledge. Okay, I mean, I see that
today as knowledge in the quantum field. And
actually, in Greg Braden's book, what I want to,
I want the sentence from the book actually, it's
the spontaneous healing of belief. He writes that
every thought, every feeling, every emotion, and
every belief that each one of us has affects the
whole quantum field. And that's, you know, that's
how I see the whole concept of the Akashic records.
There, every thought that's ever been thought is
here. And every thought that we as human beings
have or every belief, every feeling, every
emotion affects that field. Nothing is lost.
Nothing is lost. But for me, that is the best
news that one could have, because that means that
when we take care of our thoughts and choose to
choose the positive thoughts, or choose to see
that half empty glass is half full, each one of us
does make a difference. And that's what keeps me
going in the current world we're in. Well,
that's pretty much why I do these interviews,
as well, is to spread as many positive, deep
thoughts as I can as widely as possible into
the world. And I love your interviews. When I
looked down at that list of interviews yesterday
preparing for this, I thought, oh my gosh, I've
got to take the time to listen to all of them,
because they're really, really precious. Well, thank you for that. At this point,
there are so many it would take more than a hundred hours. I can tell.
But you do extensive training with people to learn the Talington T-Touch
process. It's, if I recall, three years of training. Is that right? Yes. In Europe,
it's two years. In this country, it's three.
And you do like, depending, two or three
week-long six-day trainings. And you have to accumulate, it's for companion animals,
but primarily the work is with dogs and with
horses. We still have a lot of kitty people
who make a difference with their cats in one
T-Touch session. That's the beauty of it.
So on the one hand, a person in one session can
make an enormous difference in how they interact
with their companion animal. And on the other
hand, to really master the process could take
three years. Yes. And the fact is, just from
reading the book, we've had many, many people,
one of my 21 books, people can make a difference
with their own animals or themselves. Because
thanks to the work with the animals, we've developed what we call the Magic Three
T-Touches that you can use for yourself to reduce
stress or if you're in a situation that's a
shocking experience like the fires that are going on right now in California. Oh, yes.
Well, actually, you know what? I'd like to just
show you because we have so many people who are
in situations where they feel helpless or where
they have shocking news or something happens,
an accident, whatever. And what we have hundreds
and hundreds of cases of this, because in our
human three-year trainings, you have to write all
these cases. So we find you put like your thumb
behind your ear, take the forefinger and just do
a slide up, then go in this little valley there,
right down there. That's where the trigeminal
nerve comes in and go slide upward, go a little
higher, slide up and go to the top. And your thumb
is behind and your thumb gets the trigeminal nerve.
So you are, we never understood all these years
why four times can bring a person out of shock
or keep them out of shock. Or, yeah, and you just,
or if you're tired or cold or just, you know,
you feel you've got to go on, but you need more energy, you do this to yourself.
How interesting, because as I recall in some
fields of holistic medicine, they say there are
nerves that connect the ear to every other part
of the body. There are whole systems that just
work on the ear to affect the whole body, but you
can do it yourself. And that's what I love about
T-Touch. It's for self-help, self-empowerment for you or your animals.
That is so simple and so profound and so ignored by
most people, I would think. It's just right there.
It is right here. And the hardest thing is, for me, is always to learn to do it gently,
because, you know, there's a tendency when I
start, I'm thinking of the cases, you know,
I worked on a man in, this is like the late 80s. I was at a big horse expo in Germany,
and we were all packing up, and a physical
therapist who was in my training came running
over and said, Linda, you've got to come here.
This guy has collapsed. He doesn't look good,
and everybody's just standing around waiting for
the paramedics. So I go over there. His tongue is
out. His eyes are rolled back. He is green. He
is not a good color, and you could see no breath.
So I just kneeled down behind him and started
working his ears and talking to him in German
and saying, stay with us. You're going to be
okay, you know, in this voice. Just stay with us.
And it wasn't, it was less than a minute, and I
mean, he took this huge breath, and his tongue
went in. His eyes came down. He was present.
So the paramedics came within minutes. And so I
stepped back, and they, he's obviously breathing,
so they're not bothering, you know, they're not
worried about him. And I was watching him, and
he, his eyes started to go back again. So I just
kneeled down and started this again while they
were getting all their stuff out. And on his ears
again. Yeah, on his ears. And so I got, I received
a fax, those are the days of the faxes, three days
later saying that he'd had a massive heart attack,
and he lived. And he lived another year and a half.
The poignant story about this was especially
important for me because I was a citizen diplomat
in the former Soviet Union, was there 10 times.
And he had been a German prisoner who'd been
in Siberia for 10 years, and then had come
out and was working in, you know, in Russia,
in the former Soviet Union. And he had come across, the wall was down at that point,
and now he was teaching writing in Germany. And
so it was a special connection. But the fact is,
we know from the ear work that you can actually
bring a person out of shock or keep them out of
shock. And in cases we know of, you can actually
have an effect on their heart if you don't know
what else to do. Most amazing. You are full
of practical tips, aren't you? This is about
self-help. Jeffrey, we need ways to empower
ourselves and to appreciate this brilliance,
brilliant healing potential in our own self.
And, you know, that's my passion. Well,
I recall one of my mentors, Jean Houston, saying, we, referring to the human being,
but I'm sure it's true of almost any animal,
we are born with a Stradivarius violin, but we
don't learn to play it properly. We play it like
it was a plastic fiddle. And how. And, you know,
Jean Houston, when I first started developing the
work, we have like the Tillington T-Touch is made
up of the body work that we call T-Touch, which
the second T in T-Touch stands for trust. And then
there's the ground exercises that we do. And
then there's all the equipment that we use,
these special harnesses and everything that we
have for dogs and for horses, all of this stuff.
And, and, and two important factors. One is what we think because the intention we hold
for that behavior or health or performance or
relationship with that animal is what is going
to actually affect them. So we have to hold the picture of the behavior, performance,
health or relationship we want because our human
tendency is, oh, well, that's just the way the
animal is, right? Or that's just the way I am.
I'm always whatever. One of my favorite important
textbooks is Lynn McTaggart's The Intention Experiments. Anybody listening to this, if
they do not know that book, treat yourself and
get that book because you will be able to change.
It's a significant book. Now, I recall in your
book an interesting story that I think illustrates
this point you're making about holding intention.
And it's about a situation in which you were
working on some young snow leopards, a single,
they were all sick, but you dealt with one of the
siblings. That's right. Yes. There were actually, this was at the Zurich Zoo,
and I was there giving a presentation that
evening to veterinary students at the vet school,
the Zurich University Vet School. And the head
veterinarian for the Zurich Zoo has been a friend
of mine since he graduated from vet school. He's
now retired. And so they had this, there were two,
a pair of snow leopards, and they were about
nine months old. And they were dying of an
undiagnosable respiratory disease. And they were
certain, Ewald was certain they weren't going to
save them. Yeah, Ewald being the... Ewald Isenbuegel
was a head vet, yes, Professor Dr. Ewald Isenbuegel.
Who wrote, as I recall, the introduction to your
book. That's right, he did, yes. And he was just
at my 80th birthday party in Germany on the 9th
of September. So anyway, they brought out this
snow leopard and gave me five minutes because they
were afraid it would be really upset and get more
stress. So just put, I sat down in a chair in the
back, you know, part of the zoo. And the other
snow leopard was about, you know, maybe 12 feet
away. We were just on the edge of the enclosure.
So put it down here. And this snow leopard with
every breath with was bloody mucus was bubbling
out of the nostrils. And so I just intuitively
began doing these tiny, tiny moving the skin,
like around the nostrils in one and a quarter
circles. We'll talk about why after this basic
one and a quarter circle, which is actually
a spiral. That's really the secret, I think,
behind this. And I just with no intention except
to support the brilliance of our body's potential
for ideal function. And I started there with never,
oh, poor thing, nothing like that. Actually with
what I call an empty gourd head, which I'll tell
you after how I learned that one. And so I just
started with these tiny, tiny, what we call raccoon
circles, just very close together. And I started
down, you know, the nostrils up over the head and down the neck and along the spine,
just paying attention to my breathing and just holding this feel. It's just like,
know your perfection for ideal functioning. That's our method.
If I can interrupt a second, a snow leopard,
even at just nine months old, they are very
powerful animals, aren't they? They are. But,
you know, the Eval, Jason Bogle, Dr. Jason Bogle,
he always had this feeling with the animals of
making a special connection. I mean, he is really,
he was really, and I have a picture of him after
with that snow leopard coming up to the fence
after that one time and leaning and she's kind of going, like, and he's injecting,
giving her an injection. And she's allowing this because of his connection with her.
Oh, okay. And the animal was not anesthetized?
No, no, no. Just in time for your injection.
Yeah. And when you were working with the snow leopard, you had...
Didn't move. It didn't move.
You had no fear, I guess.
No. I mean, no.
Okay.
I mean, why would I...
Claws and teeth and...
You know, animals know when we're going to help them. That's a really good question,
Jeffrey. And we found often, like with this ear work that we do with all animals,
if they're sick, they may allow you to do things that they would never allow
if they didn't need the help. They know the core level.
Okay. And you knew that they knew.
Yes. And, you know, people say to me, okay, Linda, how is it that you work with so many
different species? I've worked around the world in zoos.
But wait, because I want to come back to the
thought, the mental intention that you were holding.
Remember your perfection. And that I'm just talking to the cells. I'm just holding this
potential for ideal function. It's not my job to heal. I am not a healer.
And I don't want to do anything that anybody else can't do.
Just hold the perfection and hold this feeling of wonder. That's what I do.
Wow. We are miracles. Every cell in our body is actually a divine spark.
Now, as I recall, though, in your book, you wrote
that you also – and you said you didn't tell
anybody at the time – you were holding the
intention that this healing would affect not
only this baby snow leopard, but also its siblings who were also sick.
The one right there. There was one sibling. Absolutely. I was holding the intention and
she was watching us, really intently watching
what I was doing. So I was just projecting
that she could feel this also. Okay. So who you never touched.
No, I never got near, actually. Never even talked to her.
Okay. And then? And then – and the tail was that long.
The tail was almost on the floor down here. And I
went to the very tip of the tail. They had given
me five minutes, but actually it was 25 minutes.
And then when I got to the tip of the tail,
and Ewald and the other zookeeper, they did
not move while I was doing it. It was just like
time had stopped. Everybody was in a trance state.
They were really – And you were too, I presume.
I was completely focused on the potential. Well, only in a few times in my life have I
been around exotic animals like that, but it's awesome. And every time I'm near them,
I feel like it puts me into an altered state.
Interesting, yes. They have such a special role.
Anyway, so what happened? The zookeeper picked
up the leopard, put the snow leopard back in,
and an hour later their temperatures were checked.
And remember, they've been handled all the time.
So, I mean, these were not wild animals. They're handled.
They're in a zoo. Right. And in a zoo that handled the
animals at that time. And the temperature was
normal. And that's what Dr. Easton Boogle writes
in the introduction to my book. It was what happened. And including the sibling?
Including the sibling. Not just the one I worked. Both had temperatures.
So you're holding the mental intention to heal or to be a catalyst for both animals
seemed to make a difference. No question.
Mm-hmm. And for me, again, I really want to emphasize there is something really magical
that happens with this one and a quarter circle.
It's not just petting or massaging or stroking.
And actually, we've done studies with Anna
Wise from the Boulder Institute of Biofeedback.
And she worked with Maxwell Cage, who developed
this mind mirror to measure states of consciousness.
So we've worked with Anna actually four times. And I also had the great fortune
to work with Dr. Fritz Albert Popp in his International Institute of Biophysics in
Neuss, Germany. And that's when we found out that
the one and a quarter circle, moving the skin,
it does not work if you just do a circle over
the skin. You have to catch the skin and move the
tissue. And one circle and a little more. If
you do like two circles, like it's not the same,
because we're not... What's the word I'm looking
for? We're not present. If I just kind of...
It's not acupuncture. It's staying present in this. And that is a huge gift.
So we know... So what happened with the Popp Institute? We did first a pilot study
and we found that indeed that the one and a quarter circles, moving the skin, did
activate the cell function more than the required 17% to make it effective.
Well, I like your emphasis on the notion of being present.
That's it. Because it seems that that makes all
the difference between mechanically going through
some sort of a recipe as opposed to the application
of conscious intuition. Exactly. And you know,
it's like playing the piano. You learn the scales.
You learn the different touches and the different
parts of your hand that you can use. And then
you allow just to see what works at that,
what affects... You know, you mentioned Gene
Houston. When I first developed these different
touches, we had one, two, three, four, and five
ways of holding the hands. And then I realized,
oh dear, who can remember those like numbers? And
so we named it... The first one was the clouded
leopard, where you hold your hand like a big
paw and the pads of your fingers move the skin
in one and a quarter circles. And that brings the
most awareness. And then we had the raccoon touch,
which is the tip of the fingers. That's what I
did on that little snow leopard, like around these
parts. And you intuitively knew what to do.
I just allowed my fingers to do whatever fit.
Because you have a repertoire of, I'm guessing,
maybe 50 different... Of the scales. We have 20,
about 22 now. 22 different ways of touching...
Parts of the hand. Parts of the hand that you
actually move. And one of the reasons that
this telling-to-touch training system works so,
is we have also pressures from one to 10, and tempo, like that's a one second circle,
a two second circle, and a three second circle.
The time it takes you to move the skin around the
face of the clock. And you can learn this, you can
learn it in a couple of days, just to affect it.
We did, actually on YouTube, there is a little
video of me working on a woman with Alzheimer's,
in a wheelchair, in a senior center in Ohio. And I had been invited there to give
two day trainings to half the staff, 24 one
day and 25 the next day. So it was four days.
And then because the state was paying for that
study, and paying everybody's salaries to be
there out of their work, they had to do a one
year recording of every time the T-Touch was used.
For somebody who was crying and wouldn't go
to sleep, or wouldn't take their meditation,
or was wandering, or wanted to go home, or was
having a lot of... These are all Alzheimer's
patients. These were dementia and Alzheimer's,
right. And it's fascinating that all of those...
So they didn't want just the caregivers, they
wanted the kitchen help, everybody for some reason
to be able to do this. That makes sense. And it's
an amazing study how less than five minutes of
whoever was feeding them or taking care of
them could put that person to a place of peace.
You know...
Just with a couple of these little touches.
You're reminding me of an experience I had in
1969. I was fresh out of college. I worked at
a mental health clinic. And Bernie Gunther,
who was an Esalen teacher, wrote a book about
touch and sensation.
I don't know that one. Is he still alive?
I don't know.
Oh, I'd love to contact him.
But I was reading and I was dealing with... I
was in a clinical setting with a woman who hadn't
spoken since she'd been there. I don't know. She
just didn't talk. And we did this simple little
thing. I intuitively thought, let's just... I had each of them do this to themselves,
just little tapping like this on the scalp. This woman started talking after that.
Beautiful.
Beautiful.
The simplest, eh?
Yeah.
That's the thing that gets me.
So I wanted to mention Gene Houston. I started
to talk as we developed these different hands,
like that's the clouded leopard. The raccoon
touch is the very tips of the fingers.
The lying leopard. I imagine this little leopard stretching out the front legs and
sitting down like this. That's the lying leopard. And then you get the bear touch,
which is with the fingernails. You might go in
with the fingernails. Some people and animals
love that. Kitties love it when you do it very
lightly just in front of the tail and they'll be
sticking the tail up. And then so then that's with
the nails. And you have to have nails to do it
because it's just very lightly. And then the
tiger touch, you know, with the fingernails
farther apart. And then you move the thing, tip
the fingers over and that back of the fingernails,
which we sometimes use just like that in different
ways. This is really nice around your own neck,
you know, to do this. And that is the baby chimp
because I've worked on chimps and you know how
chimps curl their fingers up when they walk.
Well, yes, yes. And then there's the baby orang
because I worked on a little two-month-old orangutan in the San Diego Zoo who had an
inadequate sucking reflex. And you know how they
let their fingers hang more. So orang is from the
tip to the second joint. And you don't need to
remember these names, but it's just kind of fun.
And what Jean Houston said when she heard that I had developed these names,
Linda is bringing the spirit of the animals into
the work. And I didn't get that. I hadn't gotten
that until I heard her comment about that. And
she had that had a big effect. Of course I am.
Wow, isn't that fascinating? Because in those
days, I was still thinking much more logically.
And now whenever I start a workshop and what
I did before we started our talk was call in,
just imagine calling in the spirit of all the
animals now. All of the animals who have graced
my life, all of the animals who need just support
and recognition. And anybody can do that and just
you know work way beyond just us sitting here.
Now you've worked I'm sure with thousands of
animals at this point. I have, yes. And more
important to me than what I've worked with
is that through my books and all of our teachers,
many many many other people have worked with many
animals. And recognize for me it's about recognizing
the beauty, the joy that animals bring to our
lives, how important they are in our lives. Well
this is very profound and I certainly have the
sense speaking to you that these spirits are
with you. And not just with you but with us.
With us. Yeah. With us. And I assume that our
viewers will actually be experiencing this same
sense of communion, communion with life. With
life. And I'd like to actually after that first
definition of intuition, that simple unlearned
knowledge, somebody gave me a book and in the
book was a different definition of intuition that
I believe fits. And intuition is the manifestation
of divine consciousness within you. Knowing and
understanding its truth can change your life
and help you find your true path. Beautiful. That
is beautiful and I think that is a good note to
conclude this conversation. Linda Tellington-Jones,
what a joy to be with you. Thank you. It's my
great pleasure. Thank you so much and thank you for being with us.
The inaugural issue of the New Thinking Allowed
magazine was just released on March 1st. You can
download a free PDF copy from the New Thinking Allowed Foundation website.
